name: NPR
text:
The Salehs are among the thousands of Syrian refugees who make up about 70% of Jordan's farmworkers. They were working when a fire broke out in their tent — killing their 4 youngest kids. 

"We aren't the first people or the last people to suffer this." https://t.co/j2gkk7DRZD

name: NPR
text:
Review: Suzanne Park's debut adult novel is a crackling romance starring a young woman trying to make it in the extremely male-dominated gaming industry — can she find love AND a career? 

Signs point to yes. https://t.co/FfpL4ZfDB4

name: NPR
text:
If you choose to engage in racial equity dialogue: reflect, be intentional, and be informed, says the director of the American Negotiation Institute. 

This helps you to understand the impact of your action or inaction. 
https://t.co/V6Rrln6tlR

name: NPR
text:
Ten vocal ensembles that would normally be touring the summer festival circuit have organized a virtual, weeklong concert series. "If ever we needed some light, it's now," said one of the organizers.
https://t.co/6cEbHcpuEs

name: NPR
text: Thanks to swift pacing and high production values, the first-ever virtual DNC presented viewers with a compact and highly watchable two hours of political messaging each night. It was, in fact, remarkably slick. https://t.co/dJZWOGJqMO

name: NPR
text:
When lockdown hit, photographer Elizabeth Dalziel suddenly became her sons' primary teacher. She describes the time together as "a tight hug, though at times it feels like a boa constrictor's slow squeeze."

Here's a glimpse into her new reality:
https://t.co/4MhrENsflH

name: NPR
text:
"I was the hardest worker on the court. Like, offense, defense. I wanted to guard the best player. It was just a part of my game. This is who I am."

Cherelle George explains how she found a home with The Harlem Globetrotters. https://t.co/7M4UG2njQC

name: NPR
text:
Polling data and NPR's interviews with white seniors who backed Trump in 2016 suggest this key group of voters remains in play — still reachable by both sides with just over two months to election day.
https://t.co/zNXXA6wfuP

name: NPR
text:
RT @nprpolitics: The House passed legislation yesterday to infuse $25 billion into the Postal Service and block operational changes that Democrats fear could hobble mail-in voting in November.

Twenty-six Republicans sided with Democrats to approve the bill: https://t.co/ZBj1UthGvO

name: NPR
text:
The upshot: make a plan before a storm is headed your way, and remember that water — not wind — is the biggest danger you're likely to face during a hurricane.
https://t.co/ynWjPGKBuN

name: NPR
text:
The last three presidents won reelection not just on their past accomplishments, but also on their vision for the nation's future. So far, President Trump has been vague about that.

His campaign insists that will change at the RNC. https://t.co/5Mayq4PurL

name: NPR
text:
Nnedi Okorafor's new middle-grade novel follows a boy in Nigeria who vows to avenge his murdered father.

It deals with heavy issues from a child's perspective, which is "really valuable for young readers to first start learning how to unpack things."
https://t.co/MQd5lMTZ8k

name: NPR
text:
One of the 336 delegates attending the scaled-down, in-person portion of the RNC says all the coronavirus safety rules are a bit much.

"I don't like where this might be going down the road. Maybe mandatory masks today, maybe mandatory vaccines tomorrow."
https://t.co/wxJinW865a

name: NPR
text: Sculptor Meredith Bergmann will soon unveil Central Park's first statue to depict real women, a 14-foot-tall bronze monument paying homage to Sojourner Truth, Susan B. Anthony and Elizabeth Cady Stanton. @hereandnow https://t.co/yoLaAyKtle
